eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: PANDAKO-GitHub
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: MousePointerLock
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: This behavior removes the limit on the distance the mouse can move and hides the cursor.
description: This behavior removes the limit on the distance the mouse can move and hides the cursor.
For example, a user can rotate or continue to manipulate an object by moving the mouse endlessly ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://mouse-pointer-lock)).
Without the pointer lock, the rotation or operation will stop the moment the pointer reaches the edge of the browser or screen.
Game players don't have to worry about leaving the gameplay area or accidentally clicking on another application that moves the mouse focus away from the game.
Locking the pointer locks `CursorX()` and `CursorY()` expressions.

eventsFunctions.description: Get the movement of the pointer on the X-axis.
eventsFunctions.name: MovementX

eventsFunctions.description: Get the movement of the pointer on the Y-axis.
eventsFunctions.name: MovementY

eventsFunctions.description: Lock the mouse pointer to hide it.
eventsFunctions.name: RequestPointerLock

eventsFunctions.description: Unlocks the mouse pointer and show it.
eventsFunctions.name: ExitPointerLock

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the mouse pointer is locked.
eventsFunctions.name: isPointerLocked

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FirstPersonCamera
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Move the camera to look though objects eyes.
description: Move the camera to look though objects eyes.
This extension can be used with the "Mouse pointer lock" or "Gamepad" extension to build a first person camera.

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera to look though _PARAM1_ eyes. The object must look to the right when all its angles are 0 and the top of its head be toward Z+.
eventsFunctions.name: LookFromObjectEyes
eventsFunctions.sentence: Move the camera of _PARAM2_ to look though _PARAM1_ eyes

inlineCode: // Formulas used in this extension were generated from a math model.
// They are probably not understandable on their own.
// If you need to modify them or need to write new feature,
// please take a look to the platformer extension documentation:
// The implementation jumps from one quadratic resolution to another
// to find the right formula to use as the time is unknown.
+ Math.sqrt(gravity * gravity * jumpSustainTime * jumpSustainTime - 2 * jumpHeight * gravity - maxFallingSpeed * maxFallingSpeed);
jumpSpeed = -gravity * jumpSustainTime + Math.sqrt(2 * gravity * gravity * jumpSustainTime * jumpSustainTime - 4 * jumpHeight * gravity);
// affine case can't have a maximum

eventsFunctions.description: Abort the current jump and stop the object vertically. This action doesn't have any effect when the character is not jumping.

eventsFunctions.description: When this action is executed, the object is able to jump again, even if it is in the air: this can be useful to allow a double jump for example. This is not a permanent effect: you must call again this action everytime you want to allow the object to jump (apart if it's on the floor).
